annotation.TEXT: Air-hopping is also a thing in this game. If you drop off something without jumping, you'll be able to jump once in mid-air. The Sakugarne seems to be the only exception to this, which more or less allows you to double jump (and potentially bypass a few sections in the process).

As you could probably tell with those Nitrons on the first screen, some of the returning enemies have been reworked. The fish eggs in particular have the potential to be pretty dangerous (since, as you're about to see, using charged shots on them isn't a good idea).

And to be honest...I'm kind of dreading to see what Quick Man's stage is going to look like in the final release. I've said it before and I'll say it again: No one likes those damned lasers. So, here's to hoping his stage has a far better gimmick this time around.

With that music cue, let's do the usual run-down: Quint controls almost no different from how he did in the first game. Aside from the standard slide and charge, he can also duck (and unlike in Rocks, it actually serves a purpose here). Quint also has a dash which you can use continuously by holding down the button for it, which makes speeding through levels quite fun (that is, if you planned your route out well enough - lest you crash into everything in the level).

Volcan Burst is another relatively strong weapon with somewhat limited ammo as a trade-off. The wall of fire is enough to instantly kill nearly every minor enemy in the game so far (the Penpen Makers being an exception - but even then, it leaves them with next to no health left).
It's also worth noting that Quint doesn't fall off ladders if you get hit while on them (you'll still take damage, but you more or less have hyper-armor while climbing up stuff).

Though I do a terrible job of showing it, Gemini Man's pattern isn't too difficult to figure out. First, he'll spawn clones every time you shoot at him. After that, he switches to a clone shield where he jumps when you shoot. Finally, he'll throw three clones at you, then repeats the pattern over again.

Yoku blocks in this game are fast...a bit too fast, actually. Quint may be more agile than vanilla Mega Man, but I don't think the yoku blocks need to be this quick in return. It's still possible to take in and observe their patterns, but for a new player, I could easily see this actually eating up more time when compared to an average block puzzle.

There's only two RM stages for now, but they're sizable enough to fill out a video, along with featuring some unique gimmicks. Beyond that, there's actually a few extra things you get from beating the demo (which I'll show off towards the end).

Compared to Gemini Man's stage, Fire Man's stage is relatively simple. Aside from one section near the end, the only major gimmick at play here are the dash sections through fire waves. On that note, I find it kind of strange that the fire jets don't make an appearance here (then again, the new rotating fireballs could be seen as a replacement to them).

Here we have the second variant of the clone puzzle. The blue ones jump whenever you shoot, and unlike the red ones, they can actually be destroyed; specifically through spikes. Thankfully, you won't die if the copy happens to run into them.

Well then, here's something that's probably going to confuse a lot of people. I never actually did a video series on the first Quint's Revenge, mostly due to issues on my behalf, and partly due to RushJet1's playthrough - where the soundtrack was replaced with remixes from his MMII GB album. I was thinking about doing something along those lines, but since he beat me to the punch, I saw little else I could contribute.

And now it's time for sloppy playing. I don't know what it is, but I absolutely suck at this mini-boss (and the main bosses to an extent, though I eventually did nail down most of their patterns - as seen in the extra footage near the end).

First, I'll be taking out the bosses we've already seen (Fire and Gemini). After that, I'll mostly be using the buster against every other boss. The only exceptions to this are Quick Man and Snake Man. The former is mainly because I haven't nailed down his pattern yet, and the latter is because he's a two-phase fight (though in hindsight, he does seem exceptionally weak to the buster).

Leading your clone to the unlocking platform is pretty simple. This red variant automatically jumps whenever it gets near specific ledges or platforms. Mercifully, it doesn't operate on an "I take damage, you take damage" mechanic, since the clone is invincible (granted, there's another version you will have to protect later on, but it won't hurt you if you mess up).

Here we have the first extra of the game: Beat the demo, then enter the Konami code on the title screen. Notably, this actually unlocks all the weapons from this game and the previous Quint's Revenge as well. I won't be giving my opinions on them just yet (seeing as the game is incomplete, and the fact that it would take way too long to analyze all of them), but I will at least show them off.

Dream Twins is almost like a makeshift shield to some extent. The two clones it creates by your side can block out almost any projectile, and tend to deal high damage to anything they touch. Something this demonstration doesn't show however, is that you can keep the copies out by holding down the button.

Aside from steamrolling through the enemies and bosses, there is one other incentive to using this code: Beating the demo again with the all weapons cheat gives you access to a boss rush if you enter the Konami code backwards while on the title screen. This might sound pointless at first, seeing as there's only 3 bosses in this demo...but that's where you'd be wrong. All 8 Robot Masters are actually programmed in, and the boss rush pits you against them.

With the second game in the works, and since its demo is more than one stage long, I see no reason not to take a look at it while I have the chance. On that note, I'm still working on Rocks...but for the time being, I'd rather spotlight a game with promise before moving onto the one that crashes because I looked at it funny.

[Memories of Toxic Tower and Slime Climb intensify] In all seriousness though, this auto-scrolling section isn't too bad. Even when staying near the top of the screen, there's very few instances where you can be blind-sided by enemies (with that being said, there's still lava pits to look out for).
